フォームをダウンロード 機密保持誓約書 (Kimitsu Hoji Seiyakusho)

The Kimitsu Hoji Seiyakusho is the Japanese equivalent of a Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA) or Confidentiality Pledge. While general confidentiality clauses exist in employment contracts, this specific pledge is often required for employees handling sensitive intellectual property, customer databases, or proprietary technology.

Legal Framework
Japanese courts strictly interpret what constitutes "secrets." For information to be protected, it usually needs to be managed as a secret (e.g., labeled Confidential), useful for business, and not publicly known. This pledge acts as the employee's acknowledgment that they understand specific data is confidential and must be handled according to security protocols.

Scope of Application
This document is versatile. It can be used upon hiring, upon promotion to a managerial position with higher access levels, or before starting a specific sensitive project. It strictly prohibits the removal of data from company premises (including forwarding emails to personal accounts) and using company knowledge for personal gain or for the benefit of a competitor.
